sentence.text: The Saturday Review on 16th May , 1857 , the day after the Lords debate , launched a characteristically scathing attack on the Duke of Buccleuch 's appointment as judge .
ROGER JOSEPH was mysteriously absent from the dressing room as manager Joe Kinnear delivered a scathing attack on his players .
The scathing attack from consumer watchdogs comes only months after the introduction of a strict code of practice designed to improve services .
With what I swear was a scathing look that said something like " Wally " , he launched himself gracefully on to the air and noiselessly flew down the gill out of sight .
He pushed the Han steward back unceremoniously , a scathing look of contempt on his face .
He gave a scathing look at Alfred 's apron .
Mandeville , however , was not at all pleased and gave the sheriff a scathing look .
She cast him a scathing look .
Many doctors are very scathing about anti-cellulite creams but the secret is not to expect too much of them .
Mrs Maybury was quite scathing about it , but she is a little old-fashioned , and times have changed .
Mr Lamont was scathing about the way the Government conducted its business .
The Court of Appeal was scathing in its condemnation of this sequence of events .
He was scathing in his criticism of colleagues whose work did not match these standards .
All the police present were scathing of the legal system , saying that the stupid barrister was from [ name of legal firm ] , and would probably end up a judge .
Gordon is scathing of the collateral fact doctrine for three reasons .
She is nonetheless scathing of the intellectuals in the Hamburg legal establishment who ` did n't raise a finger " when the Nazis dismissed her father from his job .
She hoped so , hoped he was being as scathing with him as he 'd been with herself .
A previous scheme had not worked , he said , and had been the subject of a scathing report from the Commons Public Accounts Committee .
